 We do. Why is it that you have to have a flu shot every year. In fact, in 1997 avian influenze (bird flu) jumped species in Hong Kong. Before that the human immune system quite efficiently prevented humans from catching the virus. In 1997 18 people contracted bird flu and 6 died. The reason there weren't more is because the Hong Kong government slaughtered every domestic bird on the island and thus removed the reservoir. They were unsuccessful though. There were further outbreaks in 2001 and 2002. Last month there were two confirmed cases - one died. Two others are suspected and one of those died. They were all members of the same family. So now it appears that the disease has taken another step and no longer requires a reservoir in birds. It appears that it can now be passed from human to human. That is evolution.

My point was that, for example, I don't have 2 extra ears on my forehead. I am still a human being.

 If that was your point then why didn't you say so? I thought you were denying that every organism was slightly different than its parents. You see, you once claimed that you had studied evolution, didn't you? Or was that someone else. You certainly don't demonstrate any knowledge of the topic.
 
 So now you are raising a straw man argument. You see, evolutionary theory denies that it is possible for anyone to be born with 2 extra ears on his forhead. You are not arguing against the theory of evolution. You are arguing against a cartoon version.
 
Once again, just because I'm "different" doesn't mean that I have 2 extra ears because my parents' egg just decided to change one day. I am still a human being, not a different specie.

 But evolutionary theory doesn't claim that species arise in a single generation. How does it make your point to argue against claims that evolutionary biologists don't make? In fact, is it honest to misrepresent evolutionary theory?
 
 
I'm not talking about evolving viruses, I'm talking about evolving SPECIES.

 
 Well, ok. You're wrong because evolving viruses are examples of evolution, as are bacteria and the new strains that have become resistant to antibiotics. But if you want some examples I'll give three. I certainly hope that you have the courtesy to read them and actually think about them.
 
 
Well, evolution says that everything evolved over "millions of years", correct?

 Not necessarily.
 
Let's say it takes a certain species 1 million years to evolve. That means that every 100 years of its "evolving process" we should be able to see 1,000 mutations! In the last 100 years, what SPECIES have we seen evolve 1,000 times? (Into an entirely new species, no less.)

 Possibly its because you don't understand the mechanisms and how they work that you equate evolution with the formation of new species. Evolution has to do with populations - not necessarily species.
 
 Example 1: Apples are native to Europe and were introduced by settlers to North America. In the early 1800s, apples were introduced to Ohio, where they did quite well. However, around 1850 the Ohio apple crops began to be infested with worms - maggots actually. Investigation of the source seems to be the hawthorn maggot fly. However, the hawthorn maggot fly and the apple maggot fly have different breeding seasons that have the effect of reproductively isolating each population from the other. It is unknown (but probably possible) that they could interbreed if they became sexually mature at the same time of year, it has not been observed and they always prefer the plant on which they were born - apple or hawthorn. Since 1850 similar new populations of maggot fly have infested cherries and pears.
 
 Example 2: Brown bears have a very large range around the northern hemisphere. DNA studies have shown that they are genetically quite similar with only slight differences. However, the brown bears of the Admiralty, Baranof and Chichagof islands show significant differencts, although they are still able to interbreed with other brown bears, and in fact look like other brown bears. But genetically, the brown bears of the ABC islands are more closely similar to the polar bear than to other brown bears. In addition to the double layered white fur (actually colorless), polar bears have several characteristics of the head, teeth, ears, neck, limbs, and feet that are different from brown bears. And yet, polar bears are universally recognized as a separate species that is reproductively isolated from the brown bears. But in zoos, they will interbreed freely with any of the subspecies of brown bear and produce fertile offspring.
 
 Example 3: Herring gulls (Larus argentatus) and lesser black-backed gulls (Larus fuscus) share a common range in northern Europe and Great Britain. They are separate species and do not congregate together and rarely interbreed, even in captivity. The herring gull ranges to the west out to the islands of the North Atlantic to Iceland and southern Greenland to North America. They can be found across North America to Alaska and into Siberia. As one gets farther and farther away from Europe, the birds begin to accumulate slight differences in appearance, but the entire population is continuous and constantly interbreeding with surrounding populations. If you cross Siberia and northern Asia and arrive back in Europe, you will find that even though you followed the herring gull to the west, you would be arrive back in Europe studying the lesser black-backed gull. It seems that they are a single large population whose geographical extremes have accumulates so many slight differences that they are, for all practical purposes, a separate species.
 
 Now if you want to discuss evolution, please don't invent straw man examples of things that evolutionary biologists don't claim. To argue against real evolutionary theory is one thing. To invent a cartoon and represent it as evolutionary biology is dishonest.

It is not possible for any animal to lay an egg that is "somewhat different but somewhat the same". DNA just doesn't work that way.

 You're obviously either not listening to what I am saying or not wanting to understand it. Okay, I'm going to explain it one more time. Here's how it goes:
 
 1.) Everyone's a sinner. No matter what. We all have sinful desires. Period.
 
 2.) Christ died for us on the cross so that we wouldn't have to sacrifice animals anymore. He came as the ultimate sacrifice for our sins.
 
 3.) If you want to be saved, all you have to do is ask Christ to come into your heart, ask Him to govern your thoughts, conscience, actions, etc., and ask Him to forgive you when you sin.
 
 4.) Then when you sin, all you have to do is (HONESTLY) ask for forgiveness.
 
 
 
 
ok, so then domer (the cereal killer) is in heaven right now; he forgived all the families he broke up through the longest confession ever written in judicial history. he even became a born-again christian. same thing with son of sam; he is a born-again christian...it seems like you can get away with murder (no pun intended) in dealing with god.

 
 5.) Yes, God can forgive murderers, rapists, thiefs, etc. That's what's so wonderful about Him. There are consequences for your actions, though. (Murder-death penalty, stealing-jail/fine, speeding-fine, etc.)
 
 6.) If you say to yourself, "hey, why don't I go murder and then ask God for forgiveness?" that doesn't work. God does not forgive those who simply want a quick ticket into heaven. He forgives those who HONESTLY AND SINCERELY ask for forgiveness after they do something that they truly REGRET.
 
 7.) How are we to know who truly deserves for forgiveness? Is that for you to judge? No, that is for God to judge. If somebody goes around doing bad things without remorse and then asking for forgiveness, he will receive the due penalty for his perversion when he meets his Maker.
